{{Infobox person | name = Suhail Galadari | image = Suhail Galadari.jpg | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1977|7|08|df=y}} | birth_place = UAE, Dubai | residence = [[Dubai]], [[UAE]] | nationality = Emirati | education = Edwardes College Peshawar http://www.edwardes.edu.pk/
Al Mawakeb School (Dubai) https://almawakeb.sch.ae/
Brighton College (London) | occupation = Director of "Galadari Brothers LLC" | known_for = Investments, industry, media outlets (most notably ''[[Khaleej Times]]'') | networth = | spouse = | relatives = [[Abdul Latif Galadari|Abdul latif Al Galadari]] (father) | website = }} '''Suhail Abdul Latif Galadari''' ({{lang-ar|سهيل عبد اللطيف كلداري}}) is an Emirati businessman born on 8 July 1977 in [[Dubai]], [[UAE]]. He completed a part of his education in his ancestral city Peshawar (Pakistan) while the remaining was in Dubai (UAE) and London (UK). He is a shareholder via [[Galadari Printing and Publishing]] in the UAE's prominent English language newspaper ''[[Khaleej Times]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/aboutus.asp|title=About us|publisher=''Khaleej Times''}}{{cite web|url=http://ppinewsagency.com/83172/khaleej-times-lauds-emirates-business-icon-sohail-alzarooni/|title=Khaleej Times lauds Emirates business Icon Sohail Alzarooni - Pakistan Press International|publisher=}} which was founded in 1978 with extensive readership and pan-Arab presence in print media. Galadari Brothers LLC has investments in print and online media in the [[Middle East]]. Other companies under the Galadari Group in the UAE include [[Mazda]] UAE,{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/kt-article-display-1.asp?xfile=data/uaebusiness/2013/March/uaebusiness_March324.xml§ion=uaebusiness|author= |title=Galadari Automobiles opens House of Mazda showroom|publisher=''Khaleej Times''|date=21 March 2013|accessdate=14 October 2013|language=Arabic}}[http://www.me-newswire.net/ar/news/%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D9%84%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%AA%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%AD-%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%B9%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%B6-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B7%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%AA-%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B2%D8%AF%D8%A7/ar ME Newswire: كلداري للسيارات تفتتح قاعة العرض المتطورة "بيت مازدا"] {{ar icon}} [[Baskin Robbins]] Ice Cream, Galadari Sri Lanka Hotel, Galadari Construction, JCB General heavy equipment. The group also has stakes in Galadari Cement in Karachi, Pakistan. Suhail Galadari is also founder of the trading company "Suhail Abdul Latif Galadari Trading Establishment"{{cite web|url=http://are.bizdirlib.com/dubai_business_directory/SUHAIL_ABDULLATIF_GALADARI_TRADING_EST._0|title=SUHAIL ABDULLATIF GALADARI TRADING EST. - United Arab Emirates Business Directory|publisher=}} headquartered in Dubai, UAE.[http://www.tradebanq.com/company/1000564/SUHAIL-ABDULLATIF-GALADARI-TRADING-EST-.html TradeBanq: Suhail Abdullatif Galadari Trading - Company Description] He has invited several [[Bollywood]] stars to UAE due to their popularity in the region.{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/wknd/wknd_article.asp?xfile=/data/wkndentertainment/2011/November/wkndentertainment_November6.xml§ion=wkndentertainment|author=|title=Stars Unlimited - Glam meets newsies|publisher=wknd. Magazine|date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=14 October 2013}} Suhail inaugurated the state-of-the-art Mazda showroom on Sheikh Zayed Road which strengthened the tie between Galadari Automobiles Co. Ltd. and Mazda Motor Corporation.{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/nation/inside.asp?xfile=/data/nationgeneral/2013/March/nationgeneral_March423.xml§ion=nationgeneral|title=Dh120million facility marks milestone in GAL-Mazda ties - Khaleej Times|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.galadarigroup.com/galadari-automobiles-inaugurates-state-of-the-art-house-of-mazda-showroom/|title=Galadari Brothers Group - Galadari Automobiles inaugurates state-of-the-art house of Mazda Showroom|publisher=}} Suhail lives in Dubai and his group spearhead ''Khaleej Times'' is the media partner of Peshawar Zalmi cricket team, which won the 2017 PSL title after defeating Quetta Gladiators in Lahore in March. Suhail Galadari also co-owns the Benoni Zalmi franchise {{Cite web|url=https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sport/local/dubai-owners-enter-the-big-league|title=Dubai owners enter the big league|last=Jose|first=James|website=www.khaleejtimes.com|access-date=2018-07-25}}. ==Personal life== Suhail is the eldest son of the late [[Abdul Latif Galadari|Abdul Latif Al Galadari]].[http://m.gulfnews.com/galadari-passes-away-1.380635 ''Gulf News'': Abdul Latif Ebrahim Galadari passes away] Bollywood actors like [[Ranbir Kapoor]], [[Saif Ali Khan]], [[Akshay Kumar]], [[Salman Khan]], [[Amitabh Bachchan]] often visit him in the Dubai-located headquarters of ''[[Khaleej Times]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.ae/search?q=suhail+galadari&espv=2&biw=1375&bih=687&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ei=y7OOVei-HaLnyQPAgZ-IDg&ved=0CAcQ_AUoAQ|title=suhail galadari - Google|publisher=}} [[Akshay Kumar]], [[Kajal]], [[Anupam Kher]] promote [[Special Chabbis]] in Dubai with Galadari and his newspaper.{{cite web|url=http://www.pinkvilla.com/taxonomy/term/14336|title=Kajal - PINKVILLA|publisher=}} He welcomed Saif Ali Khan and Kareena Kapoor in ''Khaleej Times'' headquarter on 7 November 2009.{{cite web|url=http://play.tojsiab.com/bmN2U21nVXpGY28z|title=Play - Suhail-galadari-with-saif-ali-khan-kareena-kapoor-in-dubai|publisher=}}http://www.pakistan.tv/videos-suhail-galadari-with-saif-ali-khan-%5BncvSmgUzFco%5D.cfm Bollywood films and Indian music videos have featured his newspaper and he has also granted permission to use his SL65 Black Series for movies.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tsN9vouq-nk&feature=youtu.be|title=OFFICIAL: 'Satakli' FULL VIDEO Song - Happy New Year - Shah Rukh Khan - Sukhwinder Singh|date=11 November 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}} ==References== [[File:Suhail Galadari.png|thumb|Mr Suhail Abdul Latif Galadari of Galadari Brothers LLC hands over the Best Actor (Critics Choice) Male award to [[Amitabh Bachchan]] for the movie '[[Piku]]' at TOIFA on Friday, March 18, 2016 in Dubai.]] [[File:Race 2 stars with Suhail Galadari at Khaleej Times (10).jpg|thumb|Suhail Galadari (right) with Bollywood star [[Saif Ali Khan]] (left)]] [[File:Salman-Suhail.jpg|thumb|Suhail Galadari (right) with Bollywood actor [[Salman Khan]] (left)]] {{reflist}} *[http://www.mediander.com/connects/40786642/suhail-galadari/ mediander.com] ==External links== {{commonscatinline}} *[https://www.facebook.com/galadari1 Facebook] *[https://instagram.com/sohailgaladari/ Instagram] *[[:Category:people from Peshawar]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Galadari, Suhail}} [[Category:Emirati businesspeople]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Emirati people of Pakistani descent]]

{{Orphan|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Suphachai Chearavanont | image = file:01 คุณศุภชัย_edit (2).jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1967|03|24}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]}} | nationality = Thai | occupation = Chief Executive Officer, Charoen Pokphand Group / Chairman of the Executive Committee, True Corporation Plc. | alma_mater = [[Boston University]]
[[Assumption College (Thailand)|Assumption College]] }} '''Suphachai Chearavanont''' ({{lang-th|ศุภชัย เจียรวนนท์}}, {{RTGS|''Suphachai Chiarawanon''}}; {{lang-zh|謝榕仁}}; 24 March 1967) CEO of Charoen Pokphand (CP) Group and Chairman of the Executive Committee of [[True Corporation|True Corporation Plc]]. He is a member of the Thai Government’s Independent Committee for Educational Reform appointed by Thai Prime Minister, General Prayut Chan-o-cha. Born on March 24, 1967, Suphachai is the fourth child of [[Dhanin Chearavanont]], Thailand's wealthiest billionaire, Senior Chairman of [[Charoen Pokphand|CP Group]], one of the world's largest agro-industrial conglomerates, and [[Chearavanont family|Khunying Tawee Chearavanont]]. Suphachai Chearavanont graduated from [[Boston University]], United States with a bachelor of business administration in financial management. He is married to Busadee Chearavanont and the couple has two sons and a daughter. Under Suphachai's leadership, True Corporation grew 1,000% from sales of less than $300 million to over $3 billion within less than 10 years. Since founding the wireless carrier arm in 2003, True saw its subscribers increase from 0 to 24 million under Suphachai's leadership. It also saw subscribers for Pay TV, True Visions, increase from less than 200,000 households, to some 1.6 million households. ==Early career== While in the US after graduating, Suphachai was an intern at a petrochemical factory in Houston Texas. On his return to Thailand he gained work experience at Siam Makro, a company in which CP Group was then a shareholder. He also gained financial experience by working with Soltext Federal Credit Union in the US and Vinylthai, one of Thailand’s leading petrochemical companies. He joined TelecomAsia Corporation, Thailand’s largest telecommunication company, in 1992 and worked his way up from a Senior Officer to senior management where his positions included chief operations and planning officer, executive vice-president for business, and senior vice-president for planning, project coordination and support.Supattha Sukchoo and Napaporn Chaikhankaew, May 3, 2012. http://www.gotomanager.com/news/printnews.aspx?id=94068Pattanapan Wongpan and Disanee Nakcharoen., Suphachai Chearavanont: Dream Catcher CEO Making of True.{{Dead link|date=April 2013}} {{Dead link|date=April 2013}} He also served as chief operations officer of UTV Cable Television and founded a number of subsidiaries for the [[True Corporation|TelecomAsia Group]], such as Asia Wireless Communication Company Limited, a PCT (Person Communication Telephone) operator; Asia Infonet Company Limited, which operates internet businesses; Asia Multimedia Company Limited, a broadband operator; and Wire and Wireless Company Limited, a construction and distribution business. ==Professional career== ===Starting the telecommunications business=== The years 1992 to 1996 were a boom era for the Thai telecommunications industry. The government had granted concessions to allow the private sector to invest in fixed-line, mobile and other new telecom services. Many private companies received both domestic and overseas loans to invest in the Thai telecom business. CP Group was one of the few privately owned Thai companies with the potential to operate such a business and it was invited to compete with foreign companies in a bid for concessions, which CP Group won. Suphachai first worked in the company’s operations room and gradually gained knowledge about the fixed-line business where he worked as the senior officer for the president’s office. He was promoted until he was responsible for managing network rollout, being responsible for the overview of the business and for leading the installation of a network of 2.6 million fixed-line phones. The network was successfully installed within two years. As with most Thai companies, TelecomAsia was affected by the 1997 Asian financial crisis which saw the Thai Baht collapse from 25 Baht/USD to 55 Baht/USD. The company’s debt almost doubled to around 90 billion Baht and it was unable to repay its obligations within the due date and had to negotiate delayed repayment and enter a restructuring process. Suphachai explained to creditors that the fixed-line business was still growing and that evolving technology would lead to the development of data services which TelecomAsia would be able to commercially exploit. The creditors approved TelecomAsia’s restructured debt-repayment program. Once the economy had recovered from the Asian financial crisis, the company developed a diverse range of new marketing activities which helped improve its financial position and revenue base. In 1999 Suphachai was promoted to the position of President and CEO. ===Recovery and consolidation=== In 2003, Suphachai and then TelecomAsia invested heavily in building up the country's third national wireless carrier, over a decade behind competitors. TA Orange grew rapidly during its first years under heavy and innovative marketing campaign. Suphachai and TA Orange soon ran into trouble when France Telecom acquired Orange (UK) and France Telecom refused to increase capital and funding into the TA Orange joint venture. TA Orange, thus, was unable to keep up with competitor investments and expand its network fast enough. In 2005, TelecomAsia finally struck a deal to buyout France Telecom's stake in TA Orange for 1 Thai Baht. Upon the buyback of TA Orange, TelecomAsia transformed itself into "True Corporation". It rebranded under a fresh and modern logo. It consolidated into True Mobile, which evolved from TA Orange, and True Online, which evolved from TelecomAsia's internet broadband business. Suphachai soon also took a controlling stake in UBC, then the country's leading independent pay TV provider, and transformed it into True Visions. Under Suphachai's leadership, TelecomAsia transformed from a fix line phone provider to Thailand's leading telecommunications conglomerate, being Thailand's largest internet service provider, cable/pay TV provider, and the country's third largest wireless carrier with some 24 million subscribers. Under his leadership, True Corporation grew 1,000% from sales of less than $300 million to over $3 billion within less than 10 years. In June 2015 Suphachai was presented with the “2015 Frost & Sullivan Asia Pacific Telecom CEO of the Year” award at The Asia Pacific ICT Awards in Singapore for his leadership and outstanding achievements in developing the telecommunications industry within the Asia Pacific region. He was selected as the award recipient by a panel of judges comprising top executives from leading telecommunications companies across the region as well as analysts from Frost & Sullivan.{{cite web|title=Frost & Sullivan Award 2015|url=http://www3.truecorp.co.th/the_asia_pacific_ict_awards/index_en.html}} In the same month, Suphachai was elected President of The Telecommunications Association of Thailand under The Royal Patronage. ==Work experience== * Present: CEO, Charoen Pokphand Group * 2015-2016: Vice Chairman, Charoen Pokphand Group * Present: Chairman of the Executive Committee, True Corporation Plc. * 1999–February 20, 2017: President & CEO, True Corporation Plc. * 2006–Present: Chief Executive Officer, True Visions Plc. * 2002–Present: Chief Executive Officer, True Move Co., Ltd. * 2011–Present: President & Chief Executive Officer, Real Move Co., Ltd. * 2001–Present: Chairman, Pantavanij Co., Ltd. * 2000-2005: Chairman, Freewill Solutions Co., Ltd. * 1999–Present: Chairman, Wire & Wireless Co., Ltd. * 1997: Senior Executive Vice President, TelecomAsia Plc. * 1996: **Executive Vice President, Business Operations, TelecomAsia Plc. **President, Asia Multimedia Co., Ltd. * 1995: **General Manager, East Region, TelecomAsia Plc. **Chief Operating Officer, UTV Cable Network Plc. **Managing Director, Wire & Wireless Co., Ltd. * 1994: Senior Vice President, Planning and Project Coordination & Support TelecomAsia Plc. * 1993: Vice President, Operations Room, TelecomAsia Plc. * 1992: Senior Officer, President’s Office, TelecomAsia Plc. * 1991: 2 years with Vinythai Co., Ltd. * 1990: 1 year with Soltex Federal Credit Union, USA * 1989: 1 year with Siam Makro Co., Ltd. ==Directorships== * [[True Corporation]] Plc * True Move Co., Ltd. * True Visions Plc. * and other subsidiaries of True Corporation Plc. * Pantavanij Co., Ltd. * Asia Freewill Co., Ltd. * CPPC Plc. * Freewill Solutions Co., Ltd. * C.P.Pokphand Co., Ltd. ==Other memberships and positions== * 2017-Present: Advisor to the University Council of the Thai Chamber of Commerce University * 2017-Present: President of The Thai Federation of ICT Technology Association * 2017-Present: A member of the Thai Government’s Independent Committee for Educational Reform * 2017-Present: Advisor to the Thai Chamber of Commerce * 2016-Present: Chair of the Preparatory Committee for the United Nations Global Compact Network Thailand * 2015-Present: Head of Private Sector Team of Public Private Partnership in Education and Leadership Development * 2015–present: Counselor and Advisory Board Member for [[One Young World]] Summit 2015 * 2015–present: President of The Telecommunications Association of Thailand under The Royal Patronage * 2010–2017: Advisor to Executive Chairman of Rajaprajanugroh Foundation * 2010–Present: Committee of Ramathibodi Foundation * 2010–2016: Committee of Bangkok Art and Culture Center * 2009–2017: Board Member of Board of Trustees, Bangkok University * 2008–Present: Member of Management Committee on Nation-Wide Strategic Approach Eye Provisioning Project * 2006–Present: Chairman of the Sub Committee for Fund Raising, Thai Red Cross Eye Bank * 2006–Present: Member of the Thai Red Cross Eye bank Committee * 1999–Present: Director & Advisor of the Telecommunications Association of Thailand under the Royal Patronage (TCT) * 2005-2007: Member of the Listed Companies Association (LCA) * 1996 to 2000: Advisor to the President of the House of Representatives (Wan Mohamad Noor Matha) ==Honors and awards== * 2018 : Honorary Doctorate Degree in Marketing from Rajamangala Institute of Technology Isan * 2016 : Honorary Doctorate Degree in Mass Communications from Ramkhamhaeng University * 2015 : Frost & Sullivan Asia Pacific Telecom CEO of the Year at The Asia Pacific ICT Awards in Singapore. * 2013 : Asia Brand Management Innovation Personality Award from the 8th Asia Brand Award held in Hong Kong. * 2012 : Thailand's Best Human Resources Practitioner Award 2012 under the category of CEO and HR professionals from Human Resources Institute, Thammasat University * 2011 : Role Model 2011 by 360ํ Manager Magazine. * 2008 : Top 10 Role Model 2008 by the readers of Manager Magazine. * 2006 : Telecom Man of the Year from the Ministry of Information and Communication Technology of Thailand * 2006 : Priew Award (Business & Marketing)” from Priew Magazine ==Awards and recognitions received by True Corporation Plc.== Under the leadership of Suphachai Chearavanont since 1999, True Corporation Plc has won many awards and recognitions from various local and international organizations: '''2014''' * Thailand ICT Excellence Awards from the Thailand Management Association ** "Problem Notification via GIS" project by True Information Technology Co., Ltd. won Best Award in the Internal Process Development category. ** "True HR Mobile Application" project by True Corporation Plc won an Honorable Award in the Innovation category. * The 42nd International Exhibition of Inventions 2014 Innovation Awards ** True's Autistic Application was awarded the Gold Medal for Software and Communication Technology at the 42nd International Exhibition of Invention 2014 in Geneva organized by the Swiss Government and the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO). True was the only telecommunications company from Thailand that received a gold medal. * Frost & Sullivan Thailand Excellence Awards for Business Operations Excellence ** TrueOnline was awarded “Thailand Broadband Service Provider of the Year” for outstanding broadband services ** True Internet Data Center (True IDC) was awarded “Thailand Infrastructure Service Provider of the Year” for cloud computing excellence. * HRH Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn’s Award for Marketing Excellence at the Thailand Corporate Excellence Awards. '''2013''' * 2013 Frost and Sullivan Thailand Excellence Awards * "ICT Tam Dee Pue Sangkom" Awards for Plookpanya Media and Autistic Application under the Plookpanya Project from Thailand ICT Management Forum & Thailand ICT Excellence Awards held by the Thailand Management Association (TMA). * TrueMove H Call Center and TrueOnline Call Center received COPC Customer Service Provider (CSP) Standard 2012 as the first contact centers in Thailand. * Trusted Brand Platinum Award 2013 in the Internet service provider category for TrueOnline and Trusted Brand Gold Award 2013 in the phone service category for TrueMove H. The award was held by Reader’s Digest and the survey was conducted to consumers from 8 countries in Asia. * Thailand Corporate Excellence Awards 2012 (Marketing Excellence) for five consecutive years and Thailand Corporate Excellence Awards 2012 (Corporate Improvement Excellence) * “Top 500 Asia Brand” awarded to True Group by the Asia Brand Association in China. True Corporation is the only Thai telecommunication company to achieve the set standards. * “The Cannes Corporate Media & TV Awards 2013” for “Novice Monks Cultivate Dharma Wisdom Year 2”. This was the sole outstanding program from Thailand and the Asian region qualified for the TV Documentaries and Reports category, Education Branch, which was a testimonial on a global scale of quality content and received a lot of interest from international media present at the event. '''2012''' * “Marketing Excellent Award” awarded to True Group by the Thailand Management Association and Sasin Graduate Institute of Business Administration. True Group is the only Thai telecommunications company to win this award for 4 consecutive years. * “Occupational Health and Work Environment Award” in the safety category awarded to True Corporation Plc by the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare of Thailand. True has won this award for 7 consecutive years. * “ICT Good for Society Award” awarded to True Corporation Plc at the ICT Excellence Awards for its WhiteNet project which helps filter out offensive websites and is continuously updated. The ICT Excellence Awards is organized by the Thailand Management Association (TMA), the National Electronics and Computer Technology Center (NECTEC), Software Park Thailand, and Thammasat University. * “Trusted Brand 2011 Platinum Award” in the Internet service provider category awarded to True Corporation Plc and “Trusted Brand 2012 Gold Award” in the phone service category (fixed line or mobile) awarded to TrueMove by Reader’s Digest Thailand. * “Thailand Data Center Services Provider of the Year” awarded to True Internet Data Center by Frost & Sullivan. * WBA WiFi Industry Award “Best Next Generation Hotspot (NGH) Initiative” category awarded to TrueMove H by the Wireless Broadband Association (WBA) '''2010''' * “Business Excellence Enabler Utilizing Communications Technology” in the service category awarded to True Group at the ICT Excellence Awards. The ICT Excellence Awards is organized by the Thailand Management Association (TMA), the National Electronics and Computer Technology Center (NECTEC), Software Park Thailand, and Thammasat University. * “Contact Center Best Practices (Outsourced) – Large Call Center” bronze medal awarded to True Touch, a subsidiary of True Corporation Plc, by The Global Association for Contact Center Best Practices & Networking. * “Best Overall Call Center” awarded to TrueMove iPhone Care Center by the Call Center Industry Association of Thailand. '''2009''' * “Sama Kunupakarn Award” awarded to True Corporation Plc by the Ministry of Education of Thailand for promoting a knowledge-based society. * True Corporation Plc was ranked first in “Thailand’s Most Innovative Companies” organized by Chulalongkorn University and Krungthep Thurakij newspaper. '''2008''' * “Thailand’s Most Innovative Company” awarded to True Corporation Plc by The Wall Street Journal Asia. True was also ranked as the country’s 7th most admired company. * “Best Contact Center (Thailand)” awarded to TrueMove Assistant 2222 by the Asia Pacific Contact Center Association Leaders (APCCAL) * First runner up in “Best Outsourcing Partnership” awarded to True Touch, a subsidiary of True Corporation Plc, at the Top Ranking Performers in the Contact Center Industry, Asia Pacific Region. '''Awards summary 2000-2007''' * “Best Competitive Carrier” awarded to True Corporation Plc by Telecom Asia Magazine for 3 consecutive years (2004–2006) * “Most Promising Service Provider” awarded to True Corporation Plc by Frost & Sullivan at the Frost & Sullivan Asia Pacific Technology Awards 2005 * “Disclosure Award for Good Corporate Governance” awarded to True Corporation Plc by the Thai Institute of Directors with the support of the Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) and the Securities Exchange Commission (SEC). True has won this award for 3 consecutive years (2002–2004). * True Corporation Plc was listed among Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu’s “Technology Fast 500 Asia Pacific” ranking for the fastest growing companies for 3 consecutive years (2002–2004). * True Corporation Plc was voted by consumers as one of Thailand’s Superbrands in the Reader’s Digest Asia Superbrands Survey 2004. * True Corporation Plc won the award for Good Cooperate Governance in 2002 from Euromoney magazine. * True Corporation Plc was ranked among the top 10 leading Thai companies by Far Eastern Economic Review magazine in 2000. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * A Day Bulletin 20–26 April 2012 * Suphachai Chearavanont: Dream Catcher CEO … Making of True * Interviews in 360 Degree Manager Magazine (February 2012) * Interviews from Prachachart Thurakij newspaper * True Leadership Book#2 * Annual Reports of True Corporation Public Limited Company ==External links== * http://www.prachachat.net/news_detail.php?newsid=1321066936&grpid=no&catid=06 * http://www.trueplookpanya.com/true/guidance_detail.php?cms_id=9748 * http://www.wearecp.com/tabid/233/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/23044/language/en-US/360Role-Model2554.aspx * http://www.wearecp.com/tabid/280/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/1195/-.aspx === Interview=== '''Translated from''' * สัมภาษณ์พิเศษ. "ศุภชัย เจียรวนนท์" กลุ่มทรู บทเรียนและสิ่งที่ได้เรียนรู้จากวิกฤต ธุรกิจปรับแผนกระจายความเสี่ยง. revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} [[File:Tony Granger.jpg|thumb|right]] '''Tony Granger''' is the global chief creative officer of the New York-based global advertising agency [[Young & Rubicam]].
==Career== Tony Granger is Global Chief Creative Officer of [http://www.yr.com Young & Rubicam] (a part of [http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-news/stocks/prices-search/stock-prices-search.html?nameCode=WPP WPP]) and architect of the company's global creative community.<ref>{{cite web|title=YR.com: Tony Granger|url=http://www.yr.com/about/people#grid=112|accessdate=7 January 2015|ref=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=shots.com: Tony Granger|url=http://www.shots.net/news/article/82457/creative-monitor-tony-granger|ref=2}}</ref>
Since arriving at Young & Rubicam in 2008, Granger has attracted some of the industry’s best creative talent and fully integrated digital into the agency.<ref>{{cite web|title=American Association of Advertising Agencies|url=https://ams.aaaa.org/eWeb/content.aspx?WebCode=ViewStaff&AgencyKey=1780e2c5-ca98-421e-bfb4-0b0dcd840327|accessdate=7 January 2015|ref=3}}</ref>
He has also built a global creative community in both spirit and practice. As a result, all of Y&R's clients — anywhere in the world — get access to precisely the right creative talent they need to create the most appropriate and powerful work.
Creating a collaborative creative culture has resulted in great work and results for clients such as [[Land Rover]], [[Dell]], [[Wendy’s]], [[Gatorade]], and [[Vodafone]].
It’s also earned great industry recognition. At this past [[Cannes Lions]] in June 2015, Y&R won 89 Lions across 15 categories, holding its rank as the fourth most winning agency network of the year for the fourth consecutive year.<ref>{{cite web|title=businesswire.com: Cannes|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150701006552/en/YR-Achieves-Performance-2015-Cannes-Lions-Winning#.Vcj1n3FViko|ref=4}}</ref> Y&R had more offices winning Lions than any other network. In addition, Y&R Team Red Istanbul won the Grand Prix in Media for its [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXxRZSHc2z4 Red Light App] to protect women from domestic abuse.<ref>{{cite web|title=adweek.com: Y&R|url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/yr-wins-media-grand-prix-app-lets-women-call-help-shaking-their-phones-165538|ref=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=fortune.com: Red Light App|url=http://fortune.com/2015/07/14/domestic-violence-app-turkey/|ref=6}}</ref>
Before joining Y&R, Granger spent five years at [[Saatchi & Saatchi]], where he took Saatchi New York to the number one agency at Cannes.<ref name="Cannes Lions Award Winners">{{cite web|title=Cannes Lions Award Winners|url=http://www.adforum.com/award/showcase/6650183/2007|publisher=Adforum|accessdate=7 January 2015|ref=7}}</ref> There, too, he led the agency’s creative transformation. He led a similar renaissance at [[Bozell]] New York, where he took the agency to number three in the world. Granger began his career in his native South Africa, where he led [[TBWA/Hunt Lascaris]], a shop of proud heritage and creative pedigree.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Paoletta|first1=Michael|title=The Billboard Q&A Tony Granger|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0A0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq=tony+granger+bozell+billion+dollar+revenue&source=bl&ots=QD3vE769Dj&sig=9--tXb6-gUNwbFvfA6HWBqt_cWc&hl=en&ei=oBffS-zkIoK78gbAtLmjBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CAYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=tony%20granger%20bozell%20billion%20dollar%20revenue&f=false|accessdate=7 January 2015|ref=8}}</ref>
Granger and his agencies have won many awards, and he’s been fortunate to serve as president of several international juries, most recently serving as the Outdoor Jury President at Cannes in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=adage.com: Cannes Jury|url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/cannes-lions-announces-16-jury-presidents/239786/|ref=9}}</ref> But he’s most proud to have shaped top creative agencies, and worked with the world’s most sought-after clients on some of the most recognized and influential global brands. He is excited about the future of the business and this industry.
In a series of emails quoted in Business Insider in 2013, Mark Mackay, Executive Chairman of Australian agency The Campaign Palace, described Granger as “an arrogant leader in New York”, as well as lacking “commercial savvy” and as a “bully”. He said, "One needs to humour bullies and the way that one does it is as I have outlined in these emails."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/brutal-emails-reveal-yr-boss-regarded-his-creative-director-as-arrogant-and-a-bully-2013-5?r=US&IR=T|title=Brutal Emails Reveal Y&R Boss Regarded His Creative Director As 'Arrogant' And A 'Bully'|last=Edwards|first=Jim|date=2013-05-11|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en}}</ref>
Paul Fishlock, then Executive Creative Director of Campaign Palace, later dismissed, brought a case against the agency and won. In a long article, Australian trade publication Mumbrella reports of the case that "Fishlock is entirely vindicated in his claims that he was unfairly axed as national creative chief of the now defunct Campaign Palace," and that "The reputation of Young & Rubicam’s global creative director Tony Granger certainly takes a battering in my view. The word “bully” is a hard one to come back from."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/the-vindication-of-paul-fishlock-155006|title=The vindication of Paul Fishlock - Mumbrella|date=2013-05-10|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-US}}</ref>

page.title: Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2013}} The '''Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century''' is a [[United States federal law]], signed on April 5, 2000, seeking to improve [[airline]] safety. It is popularly called '''"AIR 21,"''' and is also known as Public Law 106-181. ==Background== On 11 September 1991, [[Continental Express Flight 2574]], an '''Embraer''' EMB 120 Brasilia carrying 14 people, crashed as it was approaching [[George Bush Intercontinental Airport|Intercontinental Airport]] in [[Houston, Texas]], killing all 14 people on board. The [[National Transportation Safety Board]] (NTSB) investigation revealed that screws had been removed from the horizontal stabilizer during maintenance the night before the accident and, following a shift change, the screws were not replaced. NTSB cited the failure of airline maintenance and inspection personnel to adhere to proper maintenance and quality assurance procedures. The failure of [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) surveillance to detect and verify compliance with approved procedures was cited as a contributing factor. Some months after, the same airline had a similar incident when a plane was forced to return to the airport after bolts had been removed from a wing panel. NTSB decried that even a fatal accident and an FAA NASIP inspection weren't enough to overcome what appears to have been corporate culture. According to Meshkati (1997), the crash of [[Continental Express]] Flight 2574 was the most dramatic turning point for "[[safety culture]]" in the United States.[http://www.aviation.uiuc.edu/UnitsHFD/TechPdf/02-3.pdf] As a member of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) at that time, Dr. John Lauber suggested that the probable cause of this accident included "The failure of Continental Express management to establish a corporate culture which encouraged and enforced adherence to approved maintenance and quality assurance procedures" (NTSB/AAR-92/04, 1992, pg. 54, as cited in Meshkati, 1997). As a result of this and other similar aviation accidents, safety culture came to the forefront as the exclusive topic at the U.S. National Summit on Transportation Safety, hosted by the NTSB in 1997. ==Enactment== AIR 21 was known as H.R. 1000 in 106th Congress, second session. [[Bud Shuster|Rep. Bud Shuster]] (R-Pa.) introduced it on 4 March 1999. It was enacted on 5 April 2000. Upon signing the bill into law, [[U.S. President|President]] [[Bill Clinton]] stated:
This bill contains many new provisions to advance aviation safety. Of particular note is the inclusion of the "Aircraft Safety Act of 1999," which my Administration proposed to help stop the indefensible practice of manufacturing, distributing, and installing fraudulently represented, nonconforming aircraft parts. Several significant provisions to provide "whistleblower" protections to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and air industry employees, to close a potential loophole in the prosecution of hazardous materials cases, and to combat "air rage" incidents in flight, will also address real safety concerns we face today.[http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/?pid=58334 Statement on Signing the Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment and Reform Act for the 21st Century]
==Safety provisions== AIR 21 set requirements for safety equipment for specific aircraft, added consumer and employee protection provisions, and imposed new requirements for commercial air tour operations over national parks. Title V established civil penalties for individuals who interfere with or jeopardize the safety of a cabin crew or other passengers. This provision seeks to deter "air rage." Section 507 modified the sanction for transporting hazardous materials by removing the requirement that the person have knowledge of the regulation related to the transportation of hazardous materials. However, it permits consideration of lack of knowledge in mitigation of the penalty. This requirement is at 49 U.S.C. 46312. Section 401 of the bill prohibited a state or local government from preventing people associated with disaster counseling services who are not licensed in that state from providing those services for up to 60 days after an aviation accident. Section 402 of the bill would expand a current preemption of state liability laws by limiting the liability of air carriers that provide information concerning flight reservations to the families of passengers involved in airline accidents. Air carriers are already provided immunity from state liability laws for providing passenger lists under these circumstances. Because neither mandate would require state or local governments to expend funds or to change their laws, CBO estimates that any costs associated with these mandates would be insignificant. In Section 725, the act required the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] to contract with the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] for an independent study of the air quality in passenger cabins. ==Consumer protections== Title II sought to improve consumer access in all regions of the United States, including those in small communities and rural and remote areas, to affordable, regularly scheduled air service. Section 221 made it an unfair or deceptive practice for any air carrier, or ticket agent utilizing electronically transmitted tickets for air transportation to fail to notify the purchaser of such a ticket of its expiration date. It did so by amending 49 U.S.C. 41712(b). Section 224 required airlines to file individual customer service plans with the Secretary of Transportation. Title IV made the [[Death on the High Seas Act]] (DOHSA) inapplicable to aviation incidents, thereby broadening the circumstances under which relatives can seek compensation for the death of a family member in an aviation incident over the ocean. AIR 21 also includes a legislative advance for air travelers with disabilities. ==Financial provisions== The [[Congressional Budget Office]] estimated that AIR 21 would result in additional outlays totaling about $56 billion over the 2000-2004 period.[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/1?&sid=cp106G5jeT&hd_count=2&xform_type=3&refer=&r_n=hr167p2.106&db_id=106&item=1&sel=TOC_0&] Title I authorized the appropriation of $47.6 billion for FAA operations, facilities, and equipment for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. Title I also provided $19.2 billion in contract authority for the FAA's airport improvement program for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. It provided an additional $7.1 billion in contract authority for the airport improvement program (AIP) over the 2000-2004 period (above the $2.4 billion a year assumed in the baseline). It allowed airports to charge higher passenger facility fees. AIR 21 took the [[Airport and Airway Trust Fund]] (AATF) off-budget and exempted AATF spending from the discretionary spending caps, pay-as-you-go procedures, and Congressional budget controls.[http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/1?&sid=cp106G5jeT&hd_count=2&xform_type=3&refer=&r_n=hr167p2.106&db_id=106&item=1&sel=TOC_0&] This provision was a goal of the [[AOPA#The Nineties to Present|Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association]] which sought to unlock the aviation trust fund. Title VII extended the war risk insurance program and prohibited the FAA from charging fees for certain services. This title provided that, of the amounts appropriated for FAA operations in fiscal year 2000, $2 million may be used to eliminate a backlog of [[Equal Opportunity Employment|equal employment opportunity]] complaints at the Department of Transportation (DOT). ==Employee protections== Title VI provided [[whistleblower]] protection for employees of air carriers who notify authorities that their employer is violating a federal law relating to air carrier safety. The bill set up a complaint and investigation process within the Department of Labor (DOL). The time limit for employees to make such complaints in writing to the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] is 90 days from the date of each adverse employment action.[http://www.workplacefairness.org/air21] ==Public Availability of Airmen Records== Section 715, "Public Availability of Airmen Records", allows the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] to release the names, addresses, and ratings held by nearly all pilots with a medical certificate. This includes the release of information to private businesses, including those not necessarily having any relation to aviation safety (the intent of the bill). The FAA must notify airmen of this clause via mail and notify them that they have 90 days to opt out of the inclusion of their personal information into the public record. If no action is taken within 90 days, then an opt-in is assumed.Airmen Certification: Public Availability of Airmen Records (Federal Aviation Administration) [http://www.faa.gov/licenses_certificates/airmen_certification/hr1000/] ==See also== * [[Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association]] * [[Whistleblower]] * [[Airport and Airway Trust Fund]] ==References== Meshkati, N. (1997, April). Human performance, organizational factors and safety culture. Paper presented on National Summit by NTSB on transportation safety. Washington, D.C. ==External links== * [http://www.osha.gov/dep/oia/whistleblower/acts/air21.html Employee protection from OSHA] * [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/D?c106:6:./temp/~c106dZ7uC9:: Full text from Thomas] * [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c106:H.R.1000: Legislative history from Thomas] * [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?r106:@OR+(+@1(H.R.+1000)++@1(H.+R.+1000)++) Congressional Record references] * [http://www7.nationalacademies.org/ocga/Laws/PL106_181.asp NAS page on cabin air quality requirement] * [http://www.peer.org Public Employees for Environmental Responsibility (PEER)] * [http://www.whistleblower.org Government Accountability Project] * [http://www.whistleblowers.org/ National Whistleblower Center] * [http://www.workplacefairness.org/air21 Workplace Fairness FAQ for airline safety whistleblowers] * [http://www.taterenner.com/whistleblowers.htm Tate & Renner article on whistleblowers under US federal law] * [http://www.whistleblowerlaws.com Whistleblower Employee Protection Website] * [http://www.osha.gov/dep/oia/whistleblower/index.html U.S. Department of Labor Whistleblower Program & information] {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wendell H. Ford Aviation Investment And Reform Act For The 21st Century}} [[Category:Aviation in the United States]] [[Category:First Amendment to the United States Constitution]] [[Category:United States federal labor legislation]] [[Category:Public administration]] [[Category:Anti-discrimination law in the United States]] [[Category:2000 in American law]] [[Category:Whistleblower protection legislation]] [[Category:United States federal legislation articles without infoboxes]]
